blocks.text: Cross-site scripting vulnerabilities allow attackers to inject malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users. The victim’s browser executes the script as if it were part of the legitimate site.

Attackers use XSS to steal session cookies, redirect users to malicious sites, or perform actions on behalf of victims. Stored XSS persists in databases, while reflected XSS is delivered through crafted links.
Because the attack executes in the user’s browser, it bypasses many server-side defenses. The user’s trust in the website is exploited to deliver the payload.
Proper output encoding, strict content security policies, and robust input validation are essential to preventing XSS vulnerabilities.
